New home sales rose to their highest level since July 2008 in January, government data showed last week.New residential construction activity is expected to rise more than 20 per cent in 2013 from last year, after six years that saw the number of homeowners in negative equity skyrocket, the pool of unsold homes deepen, wary Americans tighten their purse strings and housebuilders close operations.But while the uptick in demand has been welcomed, industry watchers say it will be the larger companies that benefit at the expense of their credit-constrained smaller rivals.“US housing is incredibly fragmented. You can have private players in any given market that are doing very well, but . . . smaller private companies are definitely having issues with access to capital,” says Stephen Kim, analyst at Barclays. “Banks are still pretty cautious with lending not just to buyers, but builders too.”Public housebuilders such as DR Horton, Lennar and PulteGroup, which have the balance sheets and access to capital to expand aggressively, have dramatically increased their market share over smaller private groups.Robert Wetenhall, analyst at RBC Capital Markets, says publicly listed housebuilders – one of the best performing sub-industry groups on the S&P 500 in the past year – will probably outperform the broader market by posting a 25-30 per cent rise in residential housing starts in 2013.Consolidation happened before the market collapsed, and it may well happen again nowWith much if not all of this positive sentiment already priced into homebuilder stocks and expectations set high, analysts say shares in many of the homebuilders are now overvalued.Some industry observers say the public-versus-private fight over land – which even large operators such as Lennar have recognised is the industry’s “biggest constraining factor” – could result in a second round of consolidation in a sector that comprises up to 30,000 participants.“There are about 14 public companies. The top 100 build around a third of all the homes in the US,” says Tim Costello, chief executive of Builder Homesite, a consortium of US housebuilders. “Consolidation happened before the market collapsed, and it may well happen again now.”Alex Barron, analyst at the Housing Research Center in Texas, says acquisition activity has risen in the past six months, with DR Horton buying Alabama-based Breland Homes, and Ryland purchasing Trend Homes in Arizona and Timberstone Homes in North Carolina.“If you are looking to enter new markets or grow your market share, it makes sense to do it this way, as these companies have strong local relationships and land positions,” he says.Michael Widner, analyst at Stifel Nicolaus, says housebuilders have underestimated the speed of the recovery and the effect that the entry of private equity groups such as Blackstone and other investors has had on the housing market by reducing inventories– which now stand at record lows – and pushing up house prices.“Here’s what we didn’t see coming: investors, individual and institutional, sopping up distressed inventory by the millions. We thought household formation was on the hook for that, the journey would be slow, and by the time it was done private builders would have ample access to capital again,” he says.In an effort to acquire land at a faster pace and ramp up construction, some private companies have hastened their entry into the public market, taking advantage of the positive sentiment towards housing.California-based Tri Pointe Homes raised $233m from an initial public offering in January to become the first homebuilder to go public in nearly a decade. Last month Arizona-based Taylor Morrison, another homebuilder, announced it would double the size of its planned offering to $500m.Aside from land, access to labour and building materials at reasonable prices is also taking a toll on homebuilders’ margins.“Over the downturn, workers left in search for alternative jobs . . . There are bottlenecks in some areas,” says Timothy Gehan, chief executive of Texas-based private homebuilder Gehan Homes.“There are only so many licensed plumbers, electricians and other skilled labourers. The framer who [usually] gets paid $9 an hour, now gets paid $15 an hour.”The scarcity in some regions of construction workers, as well as plumbers, electricians and carpenters among others, that are the backbone of the residential construction industry, has resulted in projects facing delays.Meanwhile, lumber prices reached an eight-year high in recent months, while prices of concrete, plasterboard and shingle have also jumped, adding pressure to the market. Lennar said in its latest quarterly earnings higher prices for construction materials had increased the average cost of building a new home by $1,600.While analysts say they expect prices nationally to stabilise eventually, the near-term effects of higher prices could damp the recovery of the new-home market in some regions.

Titular: Wall St rises on positive housing data
Texto: US stocks rose on Tuesday with investors bidding up shares in Home Depot and other companies tied to the country’s recovering housing sector.Overall, the S&P 500 climbed 0.6 per cent to 1,496.94 in New York, finishing near a session high after a steady rally that began just after midday.The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.8 per cent to 13,900.13 as the blue chip measure outperformed the other major US benchmarks and was led higher by a jump in Home Depot shares.The home improvement company reported that growth in the US housing market had helped boost fourth-quarter sales.Home Depot, which raised its estimates for net income and sales for this year as it cited a pick-up in the sector, also increased its quarterly dividend by 34 per cent to 39 cents. Shares in the Home Depot were 5.7 per cent higher to $67.56 and were among the best performing on the broader market.Rival Lowe’s, which reported its results earlier in the week, joined in the gains and rose 2 per cent to $36.59.Encouraging housing market data also bolstered investors in the sector, sending the nation’s largest public homebuilders higher on the day.Separate reports showed that home prices in 20 large metropolitan regions of the country rose in December while new home sales reached their highest level since 2008 in January.Homebuilder Lennar Corp gained 3.7 per cent to $38.01 and DR Horton climbed 4.1 per cent to $22.25.The gains from across the sector helped the overall market pare some of its losses from Monday when nervousness over the outcome of the Italian parliamentary elections sparked the worst single-day sell-off for stocks since November.All 10 main industry measures on the benchmark were higher with defensive telecommunications performing strongly among the sector groups. AT&T shares were 0.9 per cent higher at $35.49.Financial sector stocks, which suffered the biggest losses on Monday, gained 0.5 per cent.Shares in JPMorgan Chase, the Wall Street bank that said on Tuesday it would cut 17,000 jobs over two years, dropped 0.2 per cent to $47.60. Meanwhile, Bank of America rose 0.9 per cent to $11.13.Wall Street’s fear gauge, as measured by the CBOE Vix index, also calmed after rocketing higher on Monday during the selling. The index, which tracks implied volatility on the S&P 500, fell 11.7 per cent to 16.8.Fears among some equity investors that the Federal Reserve may imminently slow its asset purchases also eased as Ben Bernanke testified in support of continued central bank’s stimulus measures at a congressional hearing.The Nasdaq Composite index finished 0.4 per cent to 3,129.65. Shares in Apple, which have lost 15.7 per cent since the start of the year, rose 1.4 per cent to $448.90 after earlier touching its lowest intraday level in 12 months.Consumer discretionary stocks were also among the best performing industry groups on the day and rose 1 per cent behind optimistic earnings’ forecasts by companies in the sector.Macy’s, the department store chain, jumped 2.8 per cent to $39.59 after it said net profits for the holiday quarter beat expectations and raised its outlook for 2013 earnings.Saks, the high-end department store group, gained 1.6 per cent to $11.22 after it also increased net income estimates for the year.Other economic data showed that US consumer confidence ticked higher in February, further bolstering the related S&P sector.But electronics retailer Best Buy fell 3.2 per cent to $16.46 as it said 400 jobs at the company’s headquarters had been cut.

Titular: US equities sell off after FOMC minutes
Texto: Disappointing US housing data and weaker-than-expected results fromthe largest luxury homebuilder drove down stocks in the sector while broader markets sold off after the release of the FOMC minutes.Main indices fell sharply giving up some of the recent gains after reaching fresh multiyear highs during the previous session.The minutes from the FOMC meeting revealed that “many” officials were concerned about the costs and risks of further asset purchases, as the Fed buys securities at a pace of $85bn a month.Markets which started the day lower, sold off after the release of the minutes with the benchmark S&P 500 index closing down 1.2 per cent at 1,511.95.Energy and materials stocks were the worst hit while all main sectors finished in negative territory.January housing starts in the US fell sharply to below the consensus forecast, damping the mood among investors betting on the housing recovery.But the sharp drop was not as bad as the headline number suggested, said Ian Shepherdson at Pantheon Macroeconomic Advisors.“Starts were hugely elevated in December – likely because of the much warmer than usual early winter weather,” added Mr Shepherdson. “A correction in January was always on the cards.”The S&P 500 homebuilder index lost 6.5 per cent as Toll Brothers shares fell 9 per cent to $33.56 after the company’s fourth-quarter results missed Wall Street’s expectations – even though it swung back to profit on the back of an improving housing market.New orders jumped 49 per cent to 973 homes but the average selling price for those properties fell 7.5 per cent to $631,000 from the same quarter a year ago, depressing margins and profits.Elsewhere in the sector, DR Horton fell 5.9 per cent to $21.92, PulteGroup lost 6.8 per cent to $18.60 and Lennar Corporation dropped 6.8 per cent to $37.18.The Dow Jones Industrial Average was 0.8 per cent lower at 13,927.54.“The seven-week rally, while rare in the history of stock markets, has been one of the weakest,” said Burt White, chief investment officer at LPL Financial.“Markets have been driven higher by bulls buying defensive stocks, such as consumer staples, rather than riskier cyclicals, while the S&P 500 has been trading in a narrow range for the past few weeks,” he added. “At this point, markets are overheated and we are due for a healthy correction.”Among materials, Newmont Mining shares fell 5.4 per cent to $40.56 while Freeport-McMoRan Copper shed 5.9 per cent to $32.22.The technology-heavy Nasdaq Composite slipped 1.5 per cent to 3,164.41.Apple shares fell 2.4 per cent to $452.83 after Foxconn, which manufactures its products such as the iPhone and iPad, imposed a hiring freeze across most of its factories in China as it slows production of these devices.Apple shares are down more than 15 per cent since the start of the year.Shares in Tesla Motors, manufacturer of electric cars, fell sharply in after-hours trading as fourth-quarter losses were worse than expected. The company expects to be profitable in the first quarter of 2013. Shares dropped 8 per cent to $35.86 in extended hours trading.In earnings news, Garmin shares plunged after the GPS manufacturer’s fourth-quarter results fell short of expectations.The company’s fiscal 2013 earnings forecast also disappointed investors. Its shares fell 9.4 per cent to $35.54.Life Technologies shares were hit after Reuters reported that the $11bn sale of the biotechnology company looked less likely as the recent run-up in the share price made it less attractive to potential buyer Thermo Fisher Scientific and buyout firms.Its shares fell 8.4 per cent to $58.05 but remain 18.4 per cent higher since the start of the year when it announced that it had hired investment banks to advise it on its annual strategic review, buoying investor hopes of a sale.

Titular: China’s lead property developer enters US
Texto: China’s biggest property developer has made its first foray into the US with a deal for a high-end residential complex.China Vanke, the leading Chinese developer by sales, will invest in a project launched by Tishman Speyer Properties in San Francisco.The size of the investment was not disclosed but it was small enough that Vanke announced it only on its chairman’s microblog rather than via a stock exchange filing because it deemed the amount involved to be immaterial.But the significance of the deal is potentially greater as one of the first steps by a major Chinese commercial developer to build homes in the US. With Beijing placing caps on home purchases in major cities and many smaller cities suffering from overbuilding, Chinese developers have started to cast their sights further afield for business opportunities.“There is no point telling Chinese companies to mind their own domestic business. A good enterprise in the 21st century must be armed with a global vision,” Wang Shi, Vanke chairman, wrote on Weibo, a popular Chinese microblog site.Mr Wang had previously said that Vanke, which has a market value of nearly Rmb130bn ($21bn), wanted to break into foreign countries, especially those with large communities of overseas Chinese residents who are familiar with its reputation.Vanke’s entry into the US follows that of Xinyuan Real Estate, which paid $54m last year for a plot in New York that is zoned for 200 housing units. China Development Bank, a government-controlled lender, is also looking at the US housing market and is in negotiations to provide a $1.7bn loan to Lennar Corp, one of the biggest homebuilders in the US, for two developments in San Francisco.Vanke will take a 70 per cent stake in the San Francisco project, which is known as 201 Folsom Street, with Tishman Speyer retaining the rest, according to a note to clients by Du Jinsong, a Credit Suisse analyst.Vanke confirmed the deal was for 201 Folsom – a 669-unit residential development – but declined to disclose any details. Tishman Speyer, an unlisted company, did not make an announcement.The agreement was signed last week. Vanke still requires Chinese government approval to move its money abroad for the deal.“It is still too early to gauge the ultimate impact of Vanke’s international expansion,” Mr Du said. “Nevertheless, given the structural issues of China property sector, we view this as a useful experiment by Vanke to find potential long-term growth drivers.”Vanke announced plans last month to shift part of its stock listing to Hong Kong from mainland China. Along with bringing it a higher valuation, the presence in Hong Kong will make it easier for Vanke to raise financing for foreign acquisitions.Additional reporting by Emma DongThis story has been amended since original publication

Titular: Tri Pointe opens the door to investors
Texto: Tri Pointe Homes is to become the first US homebuilder to go public in nearly a decade, as investor appetite for housing-related stocks rises amid a recovery in the sector.The California-based company, which is controlled by real estate investor Barry Sternlicht, raised $233m from an initial public offering as it priced 13.7m shares at $17 on Wednesday, a dollar above its expected range, a person familiar with the matter said.The proceeds from the IPO will be used to acquire land and build single family homes in California – one of the hardest-hit states during the US housing crisis – and in Colorado.Starwood Capital Group, Mr Sternlicht’s private equity fund, invested $150m in the company in 2010 and will realise part of its investment following the offering. Mr Sternlicht, chairman of Tri Pointe, will retain a 45 per cent ownership stake.Publicly listed homebuilders have been the best performing sub-industry group on the S&P 500 in the past year, with the sector rising more than 100 per cent. Demand for new homes has increased against a backdrop of rising employment, record low mortgage rates and rising house prices.DR Horton, one of the largest US homebuilders, said on Tuesday that first-quarter profits had more than doubled. New orders were up 39 per cent, while order backlog, an indicator of future earnings, jumped 62 per cent.Lennar Corp and KB Home, two other US homebuilders, have also reported big jumps in order backlog in quarterly earnings.Tri Pointe, which is due to begin trading on the New York Stock Exchange on Thursday, under the ticker symbol “TPH”, would be the first offering by a US homebuilder since December 2004, according to Dealogic.Citigroup, Deutsche Bank and FBR are lead underwriters.The move comes a month after Arizona-based Taylor Morrison, another homebuilder, filed plans to raise $250m from an initial public offering.Smaller, privately held homebuilders were hit by the housing market collapse six years ago, depleting funds needed to buy land and build new homes.“Banks have been less willing to issue construction loans over the past couple of years to finance homebuilders for fear of a repeat collapse in housing,” said Andrew Reading, analyst at Bloomberg Industries. “A lack of financing may hasten private builders’ entry into public markets to more easily raise debt and equity.“We’re in the early innings of the housing recovery and we are likely to see more homebuilder IPOs as the market improves.”Industry watchers have said there is strong demand to own stock in other companies that could benefit from the housing turnround. Plywood maker Boise Cascade is expected to bring a $212m IPO to the NYSE early next month.Shares in Silver Bay Realty Trust have risen 10.5 per cent since it launched its IPO late last year. The company aims to purchase, renovate and rent out homes to Americans including those still unable to qualify for a mortgage. The company, which has acquired homes at steep discounts since 2009, is betting on a rise in home values.

Titular: Horton and upbeat data lift housebuilders
Texto: Upbeat housing data as well as better than expected quarterly results from DR Horton sent homebuilder stocks sharply higher.The S&P 500 homebuilder index rose 4.4 per cent on Tuesday.DR Horton shares jumped 11.8 per cent to $23.82 after reporting quarterly profits more than doubled, thanks to improving house prices.For the three-month period ending December 31, the company earned $66.3m on $1.23bn revenues, easily beating Wall Street’s estimates.Rivals KB Home rose 2.9 per cent to $18.62 and Lennar added 1.8 per cent to $42.68.The Standard & Poor’s/Case-Shiller home price index, which tracks house prices in 20 metropolitan regions across the US, showed record-low inventories that sent house values higher in November.Overall, US equities markets shrugged off disappointing consumer confidence data and continued their recent upward march, bolstered by positive earnings from energy companies.The January consumer confidence index dropped sharply to the lowest level since November 2011, indicating the first hit from the rise in payroll taxes.“US equity markets seem to be very resilient, even after disappointing consumer confidence data,” said David Kelly, chief global strategist at JPMorgan Funds. “While this trend looks like it may continue, it’s important to recognise that this is a rally based on relative valuations rather than improving fundamentals,” he added.The benchmark S&P 500 index closed up 0.5 per cent at 1,507.86, hitting a fresh five-year high. Most major sectors were trading in positive territory with energy and telecoms leading gains.The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed 0.5 per cent higher at 13,954.57.Ford shares fell in early activity even though the second-largest carmaker in the US reported quarterly results that beat analyst estimates.The company said operating losses in Europe dragged on full-year net income, despite it gaining share in the North American market.The company reported that net income declined 72 per cent to $5.66bn in 2012. Its shares dropped 4.6 per cent to $13.14.Amazon shares were hit ahead of its quarterly earnings and closed 5.7 per cent lower at $260.35. Fourth-quarter earnings, released after the closing bell, were below analysts’ expectations, however, shares rose 9 per cent to $284.20 in after-hours trading, as investors welcomed the increase in the online retailer’s operating margins in North America.Energy stocks rallied after positive earnings reports from the likes of Valero and Peabody.Valero shares jumped 12.8 per cent to $43.77 after the world’s largest independent refiner by processing capacity reported a 20-fold profit rise in the fourth quarter. The company said it had net income of $1bn, well above analysts’ estimates.Peabody shares also rallied, up 5.6 per cent to $26.56, as the coal miner’s quarterly profit beat consensus estimate.Shares in Chesapeake Energy rose 9.4 per cent to $20.75 in after-hours trading, after the company announced that its current chief executive, Aubrey McClendon will retire on April 1, 2013.Meanwhile, JC Penney attracted buyers, with the stock rising 9.3 per cent to $21.01, after the struggling department store retailer announced that it was restoring its discount programme to lure back shoppers.The technology-heavy Nasdaq Composite finished marginally lower at 3,153.66 despite gains in its biggest component Apple.Shares in the iPad and iPhone maker rose 1.9 per cent to $458.27, recovering some of the steep losses following disappointing results last week.Yahoo shares climbed initially as the internet group’s quarterly profits, reported after the close on Monday, beat Wall Street expectations. The company reported revenues climbed 14 per cent to $427m, driven by growth in search advertising. However, shares reversed course and fell 3 per cent lower to $19.70.Analysts at Nomura maintained their “neutral” rating on the stock. “While Yahoo’s shares have appreciated from the potential around the company’s capital returns and equity investments, we remain wary of the fundamentals and share losses, in particular in the display market.”Shares in Seagate, data storage company, sold off, falling 9.3 per cent to $33.92 after quarterly earnings fell 13 per cent and margins deteriorated.

Titular: Labour shortage holds back builder Lennar
Texto: Lennar Corporation said labour shortages and higher construction material and land costs were challenges for the US homebuilder even as it reported a surge in fourth-quarter earnings thanks to the country’s recovering housing market.As homebuilders try to meet increased demand for new homes against a backdrop of record-low interest rates, improved consumer confidence and a shrinking supply of existing homes for sale, they face a crunch in the number of workers.“Labour remains under pressure as housing starts accelerate . . . Many traders remain cautious about hiring as they wait to see that the housing recovery is fully established,” said Jonathan Jaffe, chief operating officer, on an earnings call on Tuesday.The scarcity of construction labourers, as well as plumbers, electricians and carpenters among others that are the backbone of the residential construction industry, has resulted in projects facing delays.Lennar said the average home takes 10 days more to complete compared to last year, while more labour-constrained markets such as Phoenix in Arizona and pockets of Texas and Florida have seen this rise to 25 days.The company said additional labour charges and higher prices for construction materials such as lumber, drywall and concrete had increased the average cost of building a new home by $1,600.Stuart Miller, chief executive, said acquiring land at a good price was also one of the “biggest constraining factors for builders”.“Driving community count and finding new locations is very difficult,” said Mr Miller. “It’s a risk out there as you look beyond 2013 and to 2014 and 2015 as the market recovers.”Shares in the company, which have surged 85 per cent in the past 12 months, fell 2.1 per cent by midday in New York even as the company reported better than expected results.The Miami-based homebuilder said net income in the three months to November 30 rose to $124.3m, or 56 cents per diluted share, compared with $30.3m, or 16 cents, in the same period last year. This beat analysts’ expectations for 44 cents per share. The quarter included an $18.6m tax benefit that boosted profits.Sales rose 42 per cent compared to the same quarter last year to $1.35bn, beating forecasts of $1.31bn.Michael Widner, analyst at Stifel Nicolaus Equity Research, said before the earnings call that a slowdown in new orders was also driving the company’s shares lower.While new orders at Lennar climbed 32 per cent to 3,983 homes – representing its seventh consecutive quarterly increase – this came on the heels of rises of 44 per cent, 40 per cent and 33 per cent in the previous three quarters.Even so, the company remained upbeat on the outlook for the US housing sector. “Recent years’ low housing starts and household formations have created pent-up demand from homebuyers who started re-entering the housing market in 2012 and are likely to continue to do so into 2013 and beyond,” said Mr Miller.The homebuilder had a backlog of 4,053 homes at the end of the quarter, up 87 per cent compared with a year ago.Gross margins, meanwhile, expanded to 23.5 per cent from 19.4 per cent.The average selling price of homes delivered by Lennar climbed to $261,000 from $243,000 a year earlier.Full-year 2012 net income stood at $679.1m, or $3.11 per diluted share, compared with $92.2m, or 48 cents, in 2011.Lennar said it planned to expand its apartment rental business to take advantage of a shift towards renting among large chunks of the US population still unable to purchase homes due to tough mortgage and credit conditions and an uncertain labour market.The company plans to begin building about 3,000 units this year, which it hopes will start adding to profits in 2014 or 2015.

Titular: US equities decline after two-day rally
Texto: FedEx shares rose despite a late afternoon sell-off across Wall Street as the global delivery service said a decline in profits for its latest quarter was less severe than feared.Shares in the company, which said year-on-year net profits fell 12 per cent to $438m in its fiscal second quarter, rose 0.9 per cent to $93.20.The results, although better than forecast by many analysts, were hindered by ongoing weakness in the global economy, the company said.Fedex also said its quarterly performance was adversely impacted by the effects of superstorm Sandy, which battered the US eastern seaboard at the end of October.Jim Corridore, analyst at S&P Capital IQ, said the company’s ongoing cost-cutting efforts would help improve its profits headed into next year. But he warned that a shift in customers away from its lucrative express shipping services was expected to continue.Fedex shares have risen 11.6 per cent so far this year, slightly underperforming US equities over the same period.The S&P 500 was largely muted for much of the day before decliing sharply in the session’s final minutes. The benchmark fell 0.8 per cent to 1,435.81 as politicians wrangled over details on a deal to avert the fiscal cliff of spending cuts and tax hikes. The losses marked the end of a two-day rally for stocks.The Dow Jones Industrial Average declined 0.7 per cent to 13,251.97 while the Nasdaq Composite index lost 0.3 per cent to 3,044.36.All 10 industry groups on the S&P 500 closed in negative territory, with the utility and telecoms sector indices experiencing the biggest declines on the day.Shares in homebuilders, some of the top performing stocks this year amid a modest US housing recovery, declined as fresh housing data showed new home starts for November came in below consensus forecasts.Lennar Corp was 1.1 per cent lower to $39.27, KB Home fell 2 per cent to $16.66 and DR Horton declined 0.7 per cent to $19.95.Shares in Herbalife, the nutritional supplement direct seller, dropped 12.1 per cent to $37.34 as reports said Bill Ackman, the activist investor, is expected to deliver his thesis behind a short position in the company at an event in New York on Thursday.US-listed shares of UBS, the Swiss bank, lost 1.2 per cent to $16.56 as it agreed to pay $1.5bn to regulators in the US and Europe to settle allegations related to manipulations of Libor interest rates.Oracle rose 3.7 per cent to $34.09 as the company that sells software, hardware and services beat analysts’ expectations for sales growth in its latest quarter.“Oracle is unusual in that it has had four prior quarters of modest to no growth on an organic cost and currency basis, so with very easy comparisons, the bar has been set pretty low,” said Rick Sherlund, analyst at Nomura.Knight Capital, the electronic trading and market-making company, gained 5.4 per cent to $3.51 as its board approved a takeover by Getco, a high-frequency trading firm.The deal, which will create one of the biggest trading companies in the US, values Knight at $1.8bn and is expected to be completed in the second quarter of 2013.Kenneth Worthington, analyst at JPMorgan, said: “We view this as a positive for Knight’s shareholders based on the deterioration in Knight’s business and share price following a catastrophic trading glitch.”JC Penney, the troubled US retailer, rose 3.5 per cent to $20.88 as it hired a former executive from Abercrombie & Fitch, another US retailer geared at teenage customers, as it attempts to transform the layout of its stores.The company’s shares have lost 40.6 per cent from the start of the year. Shares in Abercrombie & Fitch fell 2.4 per cent to $47.83 on the day.

Titular: US equities give up early gains
Subtitular: Initial reaction to upbeat jobs data fades
Texto: US stock markets failed to hang on to early gains on Friday but still registered gains for the week as the initial reaction to the upbeat number from much anticipated September payrolls report faded.Jobs data showed unemployment dropped to 7.8 per cent, the lowest level since 2009, prompting early morning buying in materials and financials stocks.“The jobs report had two components that really surprised investors,” said Phil Orlando, chief equities strategist at Federated Investors. “A dramatic increase in the household survey and the drop in the unemployment rate. Economists were not expecting this, so it was an upside surprise, even though the rest of the report was mostly in line with expectations.”Quincy Krosby, market strategist at Prudential Financials, said that the late afternoon sell-off was mostly due to profit-taking and a steep decline in the shares of Apple, which is the biggest component in both the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq Composite.The benchmark S&P 500 index closed virtually flat at 1,460.93 but gained 1.4 per cent over the week.The Dow Jones Industrial Average added 0.3 to 13,610.15, gaining 1.3 per cent over the week.The technology-heavy Nasdaq Composite fell 0.4 per cent to 3,136.19 but added modest 0.6 per cent over the week.Apple, which represents 20 per cent of the Nasdaq Composite, fell 2.1 per cent to $652.59, shedding 2.2 per cent over the week in spite of the endorsement of its iPhone 5 from Consumer Reports, an influential consumer products reviewer.Banking stocks, which got a boost from upbeat economic data in early trading, gave up the gains. Bank of America fell 1 per cent to $9.32 but gained 5.5 per cent over the week.JPMorgan fell 0.3 per cent at $41.71 and gained 3 per cent over the week. The S&P 500 financial index has outperformed the main index, gaining 3.5 per cent over the past week.Homebuilders also benefited from the positive economic data this week including Friday’s jobs report. The S&P Homebuilder index, which has more than doubled since the start of the year, edged 0.4 per cent higher on Friday and clocked in a 7.4 per cent gain over the week.PulteGroup added 0.4 per cent to $16.63 and registered a 7.3 per cent weekly gain. Lennar was up 1.1 per cent to $37.92 and gained 9 per cent over the week. DR Horton, however gave up earlier gains and was 1.6 per cent lower at $21.65 but still gained 5 per cent over the week.Among the biggest gainers, Avon Products shares jumped 7.2 per cent to $17.39, accounting for most of a 7.6 per cent weekly gain, after the door-to-door cosmetics seller announced that Andrea Jung, executive chairman and former chief executive, would step down at the end of the year. Fred Hassan, lead independent director, will succeed Ms Jung as non-executive chairman.Owens-Illinois, the glass packaging manufacturer, was another high riser, up 4.4 per cent on Friday to $20.21, a 7.6 per cent gain over the week, after an analyst at Goldman Sachs upgraded the stock from “neutral” to “buy”, citing more positive capital allocation ushered in by the new chief financial officer and valuations.Constellation Brands shares also rallied, up 3.3 per cent to $36.20 after reporting earnings that beat estimates. The stock added 11.5 per cent over the week.Sprint Nextel rose 2.2 per cent to $5.20 but finished the week 5.8 per cent lower. Earlier in the week, Deutsche Telecom’s board agreed to take over MetroPCS, to merge it with T-Mobile USA, prompting investors to question a missed opportunity for Sprint. However, on Thursday Bloomberg reported that Sprint was planning a counter-offer.Among technology groups, Zynga shares continued their slide and closed 11.9 per cent lower at $2.48, losing 12.5 per cent over the week. The social gaming company cut its full-year earnings and revenue outlook on Thursday, saying the popularity of its The Ville series of games had waned.Facebook, Zynga’s gaming partner, also fell, down 4.7 per cent to $20.91 and 3.5 per cent lower over the week.First Solar was Friday’s biggest loser, dropping 11 per cent to $20.07 after analysts at Avian Security downgraded the stock to “negative”, while Deutsche Bank reissued its “hold” rating. The stock lost 9.4 per cent over the week.Shares in UnitedHealth Group, the biggest US health insurer by revenues, fell 1.4 per cent to $57.13 after reports that it was in talks to buy all or part of Amil Participacoes, a Brazilian insurance group and hospital operator. The stock is still 3 per cent higher over the week.Rival WellPoint also fell, down 1.5 per cent to $61.22, but still up 5.4 per cent over the week.

Titular: Short covering boosts Netflix
Texto: Netflix was one of the bright spots on Wall Street on Wednesday, as short sellers scrambled to cover their positions after an analyst at Citi Research group maintained his “buy” rating and inspired buyers.Mark Mahaney of Citi Research observed reasonable valuation, a generally positive execution record, and the still early market opportunity for internet video streaming in a note to clients.Shares in the content streaming company jumped 10.8 per cent to $62.58 amid high volume. The company has lost almost half its market share in the past 12 months and had been popular with short sellers.Overall, US equity markets edged higher on Wednesday as investors welcomed better than expected economic data.Data from ADP, the payroll processor, showed the US economy added 162,000 jobs, above consensus estimates of 140,000, while the Institute for Supply Management showed new orders in the non-manufacturing sector accelerated.However, caution prevailed among investors as weak economic data out of Europe, China and Australia continued to dim prospects for global growth.“We continue to believe that there is further upside potential in the stock market looking into next year,” wrote Gary Thayer, chief macro strategist at Wells Fargo Advisors.“However, the stock market could fluctuate around current levels during the next few months as investors await the outcome of the election and the upcoming potential fiscal cliff.”As the third-quarter earnings season approaches and investors begin to focus on fundamentals, US equities have retreated from multiyear highs reached in the wake of the Federal Reserve’s monetary stimulus.The benchmark S&P 500 index wobbled at the open but, after a brief dip, regained its footing and closed 0.4 per cent higher at 1,450.99.The Dow Jones Industrial Average was mostly flat at 13,494.61 and the technology-heavy Nasdaq added 0.5 per cent to 3,135.23 by the close.MSCI shares recovered somewhat, gaining 7.9 per cent to $28.27, after the company tumbled 27 per cent during the previous session following the announcement by Vanguard that it would drop the index in favour of FTSE indices for benchmarking its ETFs from January.MSCI is expected to lose $24m in annualised revenues and operating income from January.In deal news, Best Buy founder Richard Schulze and at least four private equity firms have taken first steps in an effort to buy out the world’s largest consumer electronics chain. The company’s shares rose 4.7 per cent to $17.76 on Wednesday but have lost more than a quarter of their market value since the start of the year.MetroPCS was down 9.8 per cent to $12.24 on reports that its board had approved a merger deal with T-Mobile USA, a Deutsche Telekom subsidiary. Shares in the company rallied 17 per cent during the previous session.Analysts at Nomura said the potential combination looks attractive, but cautioned investors on the likely integration risks: “Running separate networks with separate technologies makes achieving network synergies a longer-term proposition.”Kraft Foods gave up all of the gains and closed 1.2 per cent lower at $44.87. Earlier, Nasdaq said it was cancelling some trades after the stock price spiked as high as 28 per cent shortly after the market open due to a trading glitch.The erroneous trades come two days after Kraft spun off its North American grocery business, Mondelez International, which began trading on Nasdaq on Tuesday.The high-profile embarrassment is the second in six months for Nasdaq OMX. The exchange has compensated traders $62m after a software glitch delayed the start to trading of Facebook during the IPO in May. The exchange’s shares were trading 0.4 per cent lower at $23.24 on Wednesday.Bio-pharmaceutical company Sarepta Therapeutics’ shares tripled to $44.93 after the company announced its treatment for a rare muscular disease achieved a significant clinical benefit in the second phase in the trial study.In earnings news, Monsanto dropped 2.2 per cent to $88.59 after the world’s biggest seed producer’s fourth-quarter results missed expectations, while the company also lowered guidance.All-time low mortgage rates are benefiting homebuilders. PulteGroup and Lennar shares were up 6 per cent to $16.50 and 6.9 per cent to $37.4 respectively. DR Horton also rallied, up 6.2 per cent to $21.99Among technology stocks, HP slid 13 per cent to $14.91, the largest one-day drop in more than a year, after chief executive Meg Whitman warned it would take longer than she expected to turn round the struggling PC maker. Rival Dell also fared badly, falling 4.7 per cent to $9.43.

Titular: US tax policies delay $2bn Chinese loan
Texto: A loan worth nearly $2bn from China Development Bank to help fund an ambitious San Francisco housing project is being delayed as a result of Chinese concerns about the effect of tax policies in the US, a person familiar with the situation said.The measures include the controversial Foreign Accounts Tax Compliance Act (FATCA), which comes into effect in 2014 and could force foreign banks to pay a 30 per cent withholding tax on the interest income on any loans made to US entities or persons.“They need to clarify the implications of these regulations before they approve the loan,” said the person.The Chinese bank had been in talks for months with Lennar, one of the largest homebuilders in the US, to help finance a massive housing development on Hunters Point and Treasure Island, two former naval bases in the San Francisco Bay Area, with a total value of as much as $13bn. Lennar declined to comment.CDB and Chinese construction and railway companies have long sought a role in helping the US revive its ageing infrastructure.“To date, City officials have received only encouraging reports from the China Development Bank,” the San Francisco mayor’s office said.The bank and its partners among Chinese construction, transportation and power companies have become an increasingly powerful force in infrastructure projects in the rest of the world, especially in south-east Asia, the Middle East, Africa and Latin America in a particularly intense form of vendor financing.For example, the Chinese have financed and constructed power projects in Vietnam, telecoms projects in India, railways in Saudi Arabia and rebuilt much of Sri Lanka after its civil war.Such partnerships underscore the fact that one of China’s competitive advantages is its low cost capital. As a state-owned, unlisted policy bank CDB has particularly attractive funding and an almost unlimited ability to make loans, since it has access to the government’s balance sheet as well as its own.The recent tax and regulatory measures in the US are widely seen as regulatory over-reach, according to tax lawyers. “FATCA is being used as a club,” says a New York based lawyer for Weil Gotshal & Manges in New York.“If you are not compliant with all the rules, you are subject to the tax and nobody wants to comply and in many cases aren’t allowed to comply by their own national regulators,” another US lawyer adds.Foreign governments are generally exempt from the requirements of FATCA but lawyers say government-owned banks would not escape from the new rules.CDB’s most recent annual report makes no reference to any loans in the US.

Titular: Barnes & Noble falls amid outlook doubts
Texto: Barnes & Noble shares fell sharply on Tuesday despite jumping to strong gains early in the day’s trading session after the bookseller said it would enhance its popular tablet device to compete with those designed by rivals Amazon and Apple.The company’s shares added as much as 6.9 per cent in morning trading after it said it would add video streaming capabilities to its Nook tablets this autumn.The move comes amid stiff competition from other consumer gadget offerings such as Amazon’s Kindle and Apple’s iPad.Barnes & Noble shares have dropped more than 15 per cent since the start of the year as investors weigh whether the company can compete.Last month, the bookseller said it would launch the Nook in the UK, marking the first time it has expanded overseas in its history.Despite the early gains, shares in the company turned negative along with the broader markets throughout the day. Shares in Barnes & Noble fell 3.7 per cent to $12.26.Meanwhile, Amazon shares lost 1 per cent to $252.54, which unveiled the latest iterations of its Kindle a few weeks ago.Earlier in the morning, Amazon made its boldest move into the financial services sector as the ecommerce conglomerate said it was in partnership with Nasdaq OMX, the US exchange operator, to offer Wall Street brokers a chance to store key regulator data on its “cloud computers”.Nasdaq OMX shares fell 2.3 per cent to $23.17.Apple lost 2.5 per cent to $673.54 as reports said a key factory in China where its gadgets, such as the new iPhone 5, are assembled was set to reopen after mass riots took place earlier in the week.Overall, US stocks accelerated losses throughout the afternoon even as fresh housing data showed that home prices grew at their fastest year-on-year rate in more than two years in July.The benchmark S&P 500 dropped 1.1 per cent to 1,441.59 as fears of instability within the eurozone, which faces an ongoing debt crisis, crept back into the market. The Nasdaq Composite index lost 1.4 per cent to 3,165.71.Homebuilders saw no gains despite the housing data. Lennar fell 1.9 per cent to $36.26 and DR Horton lost 1.4 per cent to $21.74.On Monday, Lennar posted estimate-beating net profits for the third quarter and said Americans were becoming more confident about home purchases.All sectors on the S&P 500 recorded losses, with healthcare stocks seeing the most limited declines.Wall Street investors continued to debate whether a run in US equities – that has put the S&P 500 up more than 14 per cent since the start of the year – would continue.Analysts at Barclays said recent action by the Federal Reserve, which earlier this month said it would extend its monetary operations to stimulate the flagging US economy, has supported equity prices.“But to push equities significantly higher, the economic or public policy outlook needs to improve,” they said.The Dow Jones Industrial Average declined 0.8 per cent to 13,457.55. Shares in Caterpillar, the earthmoving equipment maker, fell 4.3 per cent to $87.01 as it cut its long-term profit forecasts due to reduced capital spending by large commodity producers.But Michael Jaffe, analyst at S&P Capital IQ, said the company’s business would benefit from a $160m infrastructure stimulus plan announced in China earlier in the month and retained his “buy” rating on its shares.“We think Caterpillar will be a particular beneficiary as the plan to build highways, ports and other transportation structures [in China] should boost demand for its construction and mining equipment,” he said.Caterpillar shares have fallen 4 per cent since the start of the year, underperforming the Dow, which has risen 10.2 per cent.Other cyclical materials and industrials companies also came under pressure as fears of global growth weighed on investors.Joy Global, which also makes mining equipment, lost 5.5 per cent to $56.88 as the warning from its rival reverberated across the sector.Nabors Industries fell 5.4 per cent to $14.26 as the land drilling contractor also saw investors dump its shares.Shares in the New York Times Company, the US publisher, rose 0.1 per cent to $9.76 after it said it would see a gain of $100m in its fourth-quarter results after the sale of Indeed.com, a job search website.The company’s shares touched their best mark for the year on Tuesday and are up 24.2 per cent since the start of the year.

Titular: Apple shares fall after launch weekend
Texto: Shares in Apple, the most heavily weighted stock on the S&P 500 index, retreated from their record high after reports that riots broke out at one of its main manufacturing plants in China.Apple sold 5m units of its newest iPhone model in the opening weekend following last week’s launch.This fell short of some analysts’ estimates, however, and Apple said in a statement that it has been struggling to supply the devices as demand has been high.The world’s largest company by market capitalisation, Apple is waiting to hear whether it will be added to the oldest stock indicator in the US, the Dow Jones Industrial Average, as the owners consider changes to the way the index is calculated.Apple’s shares fell 1.3 per cent to $690.79 after breaching the $700 price level last week for the first time.By contrast, Google shares rose 2.1 per cent to an all-time high of $749.38, beating the previous record set five years ago.Citi Research analyst Mark Mahaney raised the price target for Google to $850 from $740, saying the search group was extremely well situated against most of the major trends in consumer internet including mobile, video, local and cloud computing.“The one big miss is social [networking] but even there Google has a play with Google +,” wrote Mr Mahaney in a note.The broader markets closed lower on Monday after briefly venturing into positive territory in late afternoon trading. Wall Street opened lower as investors in US equities were worried about weak and slowing economic growth across the world amid gloomy data from Germany and China.German business sentiment fell in September for the fifth consecutive month, raising fears that Europe’s largest and strongest economy is in downturn while China’s Beige Book found the effects of the monetary easing over the summer were limited.Stocks most vulnerable to economic growth sold off with losses led by information technology and energy sectors.“Markets are not trading on fundamentals but on Ben Bernanke’s ‘open cheque book’ policy or on more stimulus,” said Kenneth Polcari, managing director at ICAP Corps NYSE.“Volumes today have been low, as investors are sitting on the sidelines and given the various problems facing the global economy, markets should have corrected by now.”Nicolas Colas, chief market strategist at ConvergEx Group, agrees that markets have priced in actions by central banks: “The combined actions of the Federal Reserve, the European Central Bank and the Bank of Japan over the past few weeks are already in stock prices.”“Making money in US equities from this point means starting to look for the next catalysts, the next feature of the investment landscape that will grab the market’s attention,” wrote Mr Colas.The benchmark S&P 500 index closed 0.2 per cent to 1,456.89. The Dow Jones Industrial Average slipped 0.2 per cent to 13,558.92 and the technology-heavy Nasdaq Composite fell 0.6 per cent to 3,160.78.Intel shares fell 1.4 per cent to $22.79 as the company declared quarterly cash dividends.Intel stock has trailed other technology stocks as the chipmaker has been slow to adapt to the surge of tablet devices.Facebook shares also sold off, falling 9 per cent to $20.79. The social network shares have gained more than 20 per cent during the past two weeks, touching the highest level last Wednesday since flotation.Microsoft shares also fell, down 1.3 per cent to $30.78. Citrix Systems was the biggest faller on the S&P 500, down 5.2 per cent to $77.00 after Morgan Stanley downgraded the stock to “equalweight” from “overweight”.PC makers HP and Dell both lost 2.2 per cent to $17.21 and 1.9 per cent to $10.16, respectively.Energy stocks were also in focus as the oil price continued its decline after dropping more than 6 per cent last week.Peabody Energy fell 4.5 per cent to $22.94 and Cabot Oil & Gas dropped 2.5 per cent to $43.92. Alternative energy company First Solar also slid 0.8 per cent to $21.03.Caterpillar shares closed 0.9 per cent lower at $90.87 but fell more than 2 per cent in after-hours trading. The world’s biggest mining equipment maker cut its outlook for 2015 earnings, citing reduced capital expenditure by commodity producers.Lennar Corp futures rallied in pre-market trade after reporting significant rises in revenues and earnings in the third quarter, with the net order jumping 44 per cent.However, the shares dropped 1.5 per cent to $36.95.Still, homebuilders have been benefiting from improving housing markets with the S&P 500 Homebuilder index nearly doubling since the beginning of the year.KB Home fell 4.2 per cent to $14.62 after having gained more than 11 per cent last week on the back of estimate-beating quarterly results. DR Horton also dropped 1.5 per cent to $22.04.Defensive stocks found some support on Monday with healthcare and telecommunications leading the gains.Health insurance provider Aetna rose 1.7 per cent to $40.29 and Tenet Healthcare, the operator of hospitals, added 2.1 per cent to $6.31.Among telecoms, Time Warner Cable rose 1.4 per cent to $95.79.

Titular: Homebuyer confidence helps Lennar’s sales
Texto: Net profits at housebuilder Lennar quadrupled in the third quarter, as Americans became more confident about making purchases while prices remain stable and mortgage rates low.Net income in the third quarter, which ended August 31, rose to $87.1m, or 40 cents a share, from $20.7m, or 11 cents, in the same period last year. Earnings came in well above analysts’ expectations of 28 cents a share.Stuart Miller, chief executive of the Miami-based company, said: “Low mortgage rates, affordable home prices, increased buyer confidence and an extremely favourable rent-to-own comparison are driving growth in each of our markets.”The glut of foreclosed and distressed properties is also decreasing, prompting further improvement in the housing market, he added.While tight credit conditions and tougher mortgage requirements mean many homebuyers are still unable to make purchases, others view the record low mortgage rates and the stabilisation of home prices as an opportunity to buy.Recent data showed existing home sales rose in August to a more than two-year high while new single family home construction was at its strongest pace since April 2010.Lennar’s quarterly revenue rose to $1.1bn from $820.2m a year ago, while new orders rose 44 per cent to 4,198 homes. Backlogs, an indication of future sales, increased 79 per cent to 4,513 homes. The average sale price of homes delivered jumped to $258,000 from $247,000 a year earlier.Robert Wetenhall, an analyst at RBC Capital Markets, said Lennar’s earnings were an indication of the strength of the recovery.“Much better pricing trends helped to promote strong margin performance and the outlook is encouraging due to exceptionally strong new order growth.“Housing is a bright spot in an otherwise sluggish US economic recovery. As long as the broader market keeps going up, housebuilders as a group are likely to outperform,” he said.Other housebuilders have also reported better than expected earnings in recent months and confidence rests at a six-year high.KB Home’s net income in the three months to August was $3.3m, or 4 cents a share, compared with a loss of $9.6m, or 13 cents, a year ago. The Los Angeles-based company, which reported earnings on Friday, said it benefited from tax and insurance-related gains, as well as higher sales. Orders rose 3 per cent to 1,900.However, shares in Lennar, which have risen almost 90 per cent this year, fell 1.7 per cent to $36.88 in afternoon on Monday, while the S&P Supercomposite Homebuilding Index of 11 companies edged 1.1 per cent lower on renewed concerns about slowing economic growth.Even as housebuilders are reporting positive earnings, industry watchers remain cautious as many potential housebuyers remain on the sidelines because of uncertain job and salary prospects, homes stuck in negative equity as well as tougher borrowing requirements. New home sales will need to double to get to a pace seen before the crisis and this could take at least three more years, analysts said.Structural shifts, including record levels of student debt and a lower level of household formation as more young Americans choose to rent for longer, will also weigh heavily on the sector for the indefinite future.

Titular: US housing market lays new foundations
Texto: Barry Rutenberg, a homebuilder from Gainesville, Florida, feels the US housing market has at long last turned a corner.“It’s not a straight line, there will be some bumps, but the market is slowly recovering,” said Mr Rutenberg, who is also the chairman of the National Association of Home Builders.Although banks continue to grapple under the weight of bad mortgages and a glut of foreclosed properties remain unsold, the broader housing market appears to be on an improving trend, as home prices and new home sales rise and inventories fall.This improvement is feeding through to US housing stocks and analysts say many publicly listed homebuilders are set to have their best year on record.Standard & Poor’s Supercomposite Home Builders index is up almost 50 per cent so far this year, nearly five times the gain of the S&P 500 index. So far in 2012, Lennar is up 49 per cent, DR Horton has risen 41 per cent and Toll Brothers is up 46 per cent.The US housing market was at the root of the financial crisis in 2008 and struggled to make a comeback amid low prices and high foreclosure rates.But recently, more Americans have been willing to move ahead with purchases partly as a result of record low mortgage rates, which have also favoured US housing stocks. The average rate on a 30-year-fixed rate mortgage fell below 3.5 per cent for the first time since the 1950s.Michael Widner, analyst at Stifel Nicolaus Equity Research, said new home sales for the first half of this year are up about 20 per cent compared with the same period in 2011.“New home sales have been higher than expected, and orders and pricing too have been strong, pointing to a year-on-year improvement in the housing market. This is what is driving the stocks,” he said.Publicly listed homebuilders make up about a quarter of total new home sales in the US and their market share compared with private companies has increased, Mr Widner added.Last week, DR Horton reported a jump in quarterly profit and said new home orders – which analysts view as an indicator of the housing market’s momentum – rose for the fourth straight quarter. DR Horton’s net income rose to $788m, or $2.22 a share, for the third quarter, from $29m, or 9 cents a share, a year earlier.Pulte, whose shares have risen almost 85 per cent so far this year, said new orders jumped 32 per cent to 5,578 units in the second quarter.“Investors are confident that the housing market has reached a bottom. They believe the new orders growth rate is sustainable and that it may even accelerate,” said Megan Mcgrath, analyst at MKM partners.Meritage Homes and Beazer Homes have both reported stronger order numbers, with Meritage registering unit order growth of 49 per cent year over year and Beazer witnessing a 25 per cent year-over-year increase.Goldman Sachs recently upgraded its view of the homebuilder sector from “neutral” to “attractive” and boosted its ratings of KB Home and Ryland Group.But while banks and homebuilders are more confident – the NAHB sentiment index rose in July to its highest level in five years as they saw more traffic from prospective customers – US housebuilders face a string of challenges.“We are still selling a preposterously low number of homes relative to historical trends,” Richard Dugas, Pulte’s chief executive, said on an earnings call with Wall Street analysts. He added that in order to secure longer term sector security greater job growth was needed.Analysts believe new home sales need to double to get to a pace seen before the crisis and this could take at least three more years.Many potential homebuyers remain on the sidelines on the back of uncertainty surrounding employment and salary prospects, homes stuck in negative equity as well as tight credit and mortgage conditions.Industry watchers also point to structural shifts that will weigh heavily on the market for the indefinite future, including record levels of student debt and fewer household formations as more young Americans choose to rent for longer.

Titular: Wall Street falls sharply after jobs data
Texto: A gloomy jobs report injected a fresh dose of negative sentiment into already weary markets as US equities suffered their worst single-day fall in more than six months on Friday.Facebook struggled as Morgan Stanley defended its role in the debut of the social networking site amid scrutiny from investors disappointed about the stock’s performance.Overall, the S&P 500 dropped 3 per cent to 1,278.04 for the week, with heavy losses coming after the release of a significantly worse than expected non-farm payrolls report.The news on Friday that the US economy added just 69,000 jobs in May, far below consensus estimates of 150,000, came after downbeat economic data in recent weeks that seemed to confirm the US recovery had come to a halt.Investors were hoping the benchmark US index would turn the corner from a dismal month of trading in May, when equities suffered their steepest monthly decline since September. But the jobs report indicated that the uncertainty in the US economy – with adverse effects on equities – would likely prevail for the coming weeks.Quincy Krosby, a market strategist at Prudential Financial, said: “The market is responding to credit issues stemming from deterioration in the eurozone as well as US economic data that suggests we are going through a soft patch.”She added: “Correlations are now rising, which tends to happen when anything associated with risk is treated as a ‘sell and ask questions later’ asset. This is obviously a market waiting for some sort of intervention from central banks around the world.”Through to current trading, the S&P 500 is now up just 1.6 per cent since the start of the year and has relinquished more than three-quarters of its gains from its 2012 peak at the start of April.Volatility, as measured by the Vix index, rose to its highest level since mid-December to trade above 26. The index is informally known as Wall Street’s “fear gauge” and is considered a measure of investor uncertainty.Shares in Facebook declined 13.1 per cent to $27.72 during the shortened four-day trading week, which saw options contracts on the company’s stock begin trading with heavy volumes.Morgan Stanley, the lead underwriter in charge of bringing Facebook’s shares to market, has faced criticism since the offering for expanding the size of the deal. Shares in Morgan Stanley fell 3.9 per cent to $12.73.Facebook’s losses since its shares began trading on May 18 have also hit a handful of recently debuted tech groups. Zynga, a games developer that makes most of its revenues from operating on the Facebook platform, fell 9.1 per cent for the week to $6.01. Yelp, the online reviews website, lost 13.7 per cent to $15.69. Both companies saw short interest, or bets that their shares would fall, increase to record levels this week, according to Data Explorers.Groupon, the daily deals site, dropped 19.6 per cent to $9.69 to hit an all-time low since it debuted last November at $20 a share. The professional networking site LinkedIn fell 7.1 per cent to $91.51, its lowest level since March.Overall, the S&P 500 information technology sector was down 2.4 per cent in a week dominated by “risk-off” trading, but still did better than the industrial, consumer discretionary and financial indices.The Nasdaq Composite was off 3.2 per cent to 2,747.48.Apple, the largest weighted stock on the tech heavy index, edged 0.2 lower per cent to $560.99. The iPad and iPhone maker was among the least affected equities as tech stocks sold off.Shares in the Research In Motion, the maker of the BlackBerry, lost 6.2 per cent to $10.68 as it warned earlier in the week that it would report an unexpected quarterly loss in its upcoming earnings statement. RIM shares have fallen 28 per cent since the start of the year as the company struggles to compete with technology companies such as Apple and Google.Defensive stocks such as utilities and consumer staples were among the best performing, suffering limited losses as investors fled to safer assets. Shares in Walmart, the world’s largest company by sales, rose to a 52-week high – edging up 0.4 per cent to $65.55 for the week – as its annual meeting in Arkansas kicked off on Friday.The Dow Jones Industrial Average declined 2.7 per cent to 12,118.57. The losses put the blue-chip heavy index in negative territory from the start of the year.Caterpillar shed 4.9 per cent to $85.52 as its shares were knocked back by global growth concerns.

Titular: JC Penney tumbles after poor sales
Texto: Disappointing quarterly sales saw JC Penney’s market capitalisation tumble by 20 per cent, while developments in the eurozone washed away early gains for US equities.The US department store chain said like-for-like sales fell 19 per cent in the three months to April 28 and total sales dropped 20.1 per cent to $3.2bn, compared with the same time a year ago. The company said it would suspend its quarterly dividend of 20 cents a share.Shares in the group fell 19.7 per cent to $26.75.Ron Johnson, JC Penney’s chief executive and a former head of retail at Apple, has tried to shake up the company’s pricing policy and store designs but analysts said that strategy has failed to attract increasingly thrifty customers.Michelle Clark, analyst at Morgan Stanley, said the results support her “sell” rating on the company’s shares as it shows the importance of discounting to drive customer traffic to its stores. “JC Penney is increasingly becoming an expense cut story,” she said.Meanwhile, Robert Drbul at Barclays said he was impressed with the management team that Mr Johnson had assembled and that there was “significant opportunity” for the company to regain ground on sales, which peaked in 2006.Slowing sales in Europe, which had wiped 40 per cent off the market capitalisation of watchmaker and clothing designer Fossil last week, claimed another victim.Abercrombie & Fitch shares fell 13 per cent to $39.50 for the second worst performance in the S&P 500 after JC Penney, after the company missed analysts’ forecasts for first-quarter sales.Fossil shares were flat at $71.91.Overall, the S&P 500 rose as much as 0.8 in the morning session as investors appeared to be soothed by a call by French and German leaders to Greece to reaffirm its commitment to European Unionmembership.But the market reversed course on a report that said that the European Central Bank had halted monetary operations to some Greek banks, and ended the day off 0.4 per cent at 1,324.80.The S&P 500 has lost more than 5 per cent so far in May and has given back more than half of its gains on the year since the start of the second quarter in April, leaving it up just 5.3 per cent for the year.The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.3 per cent to 12,598.55 while the Nasdaq Composite Index fell 0.7 per cent to 2,874.04.Bank stocks were hit hard by the news out of Europe.JPMorgan Chase, the bank that last week announced an unexpected $2bn trading loss, climbed as much as 2 per cent in the morning session, but ended the day down 2.2 per cent at $35.46.Credit default swaps on big US banks, including JPMorgan, also touched their highest points for the year as fears of a Greek exit from the eurozone intensified.Legg Mason, the asset manager, climbed 7.5 per cent to $24.05 as it said it would repurchase more than $1bn of its debt. The company also said its board had authorised up to $1bn in share repurchases over the next three fiscal years, after its shares significantly underperformed the market this year, lagging the S&P 500 by more than 10 percentage points before Wednesday’s intervention.Mark Fetting, chairman and chief executive, said: “We are pleased to announce this plan as part of our broader efforts to enhance financial flexibility and position Legg Mason for sustained growth.”He added: “Specifically, we will improve our capital structure by reducing gross debt by $350m immediately.”Economic data released on Wednesday showed US home construction rebounded in April, with housing starts rising 2.6 per cent over the month.But the positive news was tempered by another release that said permits, a leading indicator of future construction, declined 7 per cent.The data helped some of the country’s largest homebuilders make gains on Wednesday. Lennar Corp rose 0.4 per cent to $29.27 but PulteGroup fell 2.5 per cent to $9.49.PepsiCo gained 1.3 per cent to $68.75 as it was revealed late on Tuesday that Ralph Whitworth, an activist investor, had taken a $600m stake in the US snacks and beverage company. The investment gives Mr Whitworth a 0.6 per cent stake in the company, which some say he believes has underperformed and should consider a spin-off of its beverage business.Shares in Apple, the iPhone and iPad maker, fell 1.3 per cent lower to $546.08. Apple shares have fallen more than 13 per cent since its high on April 6.

Titular: US equities fall as jobless claims miss estimates
Texto: Shares in Best Buy sank by as much as 10 per cent Thursday as the world’s largest consumer-electronics retailer led US equities lower on the back of disappointing labour market figures.Best Buy said falling sales would force it to close 50 big box stores this year and cut 400 jobs in order to save $800m over the next three years.The US electronics retailer reported like-for-like revenues up 3 per cent from a year ago to $16.6bn but came below market consensus of $17.2bn for the period.The company’s shares dropped 7 per cent to $24.77 and have lost nearly 15 per cent over the past year.Kate McShane, analyst at Citigroup, said of her “sell” rating and price target of $21 for shares: “We continue to see downside risk from current levels: likely further market share losses, continued [gross margin] pressure driven by a commoditising product channel [and] competitive pressures, and long-term concerns …on international prospects.”Overall, the S&P 500 finished down 0.2 per cent to 1,403.28, edging back above the 1,400 threshold after retreating from it earlier in the day as the main US market limps to the end of an otherwise strong first quarter.Fresh economic data released Thursday by the US Department of Labor suggested to investors that the labour market is not improving as fast as previously thought.New jobless claims for the week ending March 24 were 9,000 higher than analyst estimates of 350,000.The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.2 per cent to 13,145.82 while the Nasdaq Composite index was worst among the three major US indices. The tech-heavy index declined more than 0.3 per cent to 3,095.36.Volatility, measured by the Chicago Board Options Exchange’s Vix index, increased by as much as 10 per cent before finishing the day down marginally to 15.42.Natural and organic food companies were also among the day’s most active stocks.Supermarket group Whole Foods Markets was hit by a downgrade of its shares by Goldman Sachs, who said the company lacked upside, having gained 35 per cent in the year.Shares in the upmarket food retailer fell 3.5 per cent to $82.61 as analysts reduced their rating from “buy” to “hold”. “Whole Foods Markets is a secular winner with significant opportunity to grow its store base, expand margins and improve its return on capital,” said Stephen Grambling, analyst at Goldman Sachs.“However, with only 2.8 per cent upside to our upwardly revised price target, after increasing our estimates, we see better opportunities elsewhere in our coverage, prompting a ‘hold’ rating,” he added.Annie’s, a natural and organic foods company, climbed another 5.6 per cent to reach $37.92.Shares in the company, which opened to the public on Wednesday, have nearly doubled from its initial offering price of $19.Nike, the world’s biggest sporting goods maker by sales, gained 0.6 per cent to $107.85 as the company said it had sued rival Reebok for the use of quarterback Tim Tebow’s name on the back of New York Jets jerseys.Nike will launch its new uniforms for the National Football League under a new sponsorship deal.JetBlue, a US passenger airline, lost 4.2 per cent to $5 as the carrier tried to deal with the fallout from an emergency landing of one its aircraft on Tuesday after the captain of the plane was forcibly subdued.News Corp, the international media company, lost 1.5 per cent to $19.44 as the company run by Rupert Murdoch hit back at claims that a technology company it once controlled was used to facilitate piracy of private documents.The S&P 500 financial index was the biggest faller among the major sectors on the benchmark US index, which were all down on the day, and fell 1.1 per cent.Insurance companies were among the hardest hit financial stocks with Genworth Financial down 2.3 per cent to $8.45 and Lincoln National Corporation off 3.2 per cent to $25.75.Morgan Stanley fell by 2.5 per cent, the worst among the big banks, to $19.74. Citigroup, Goldman Sachs and Bank of America were all down over 2 per cent on the day.Homebuilders, which have outperformed US equities by nearly three times in the year to date, also declined on Thursday.PulteGroup was down 2.3 per cent to $9.26 and rival DR Horton dropped 3.3 per cent to $15.39.The S&P 500 homebuilders sub index, which is comprised of two companies and a third Lennar Corp, is still up 32.5 per cent since the start of 2012 while the main US index has risen just under 11 per cent in the same period.

Titular: Lennar lays foundations for homebuilders rally
Texto:
Shares in homebuilders reached their highest levels since September 2008 on Tuesday, as investor confidence in a housing market recovery was boosted by new economic data and strong earnings results from one of the US’s largest homebuilders.The S&P 500 homebuilders sub-index rallied as much as 6 per cent before finishing the day up 3.3 per cent, taking its gains to more than 35 per cent on the year. In the year to date, the sub-index has gained nearly 3 times more than the benchmark US index, which after the day’s close was up 12.3 per cent in the period.Lennar Corp, the third-largest US homebuilder by revenues, fuelled the day’s rally as it said its first-quarter earnings came in at 8 cents a share, well above analyst consensus of between 4 and 5 cents.The company also said that sales increased 30 per cent to $724.9m and new orders were up 33 per cent to 3,022 homes in the period.“We have seen the market stabilise, driven by a combination of low home prices and low interest rates, making the decision to purchase a new home more attractive compared to the heated rental market,” Stuart Miller, chief executive of Lennar, said in the trading update.Shares in Lennar climbed 4.7 per cent to $27.63. The company’s competitors in the housing sector, PulteGroup and DR Horton, joined in the gains and rose 3.1 per cent and 2.2 per cent to $9.06 and $15.77, respectively.Meanwhile, the S&P/Case-Shiller home price index of 20 metropolitan areas showed prices in January held steady versus seasonally adjusted declines of 0.5 per cent in December, another indication that the housing market may be stabilising.“We have been calling for 2012 to be the beginning for the housing recovery and every week that goes by we seem to be seeing greater confirmation of this. Lennar’s results today certainly adds more evidence,” said Stephen Kim, analyst at Barclays.“It has been surprising enough that volumes have come back relatively strongly, but virtually nobody has modelled in an assumption that builders would be able to build in price increases.”The S&P 500 climbed to another cyclical high but could not keep pace with homebuilders and finished the day down 0.3 per cent to 1,412.52.The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed down 0.3 per cent to 13,197.73, and the Nasdaq Composite index fell 0.1 per cent to 3,120.35.Safeway revealed on Tuesday the level of its pension plan underfunding, which was the source of a downgrade from “buy” to “hold” on the company’s shares, as analysts at Credit Suisse estimated the figure was about $7bn. The supermarket group said that the underfunding was significantly less than estimates at $1.88bn.“This underfunding amount has declined steadily since the steep drop in asset values in late 2008, due to improved market returns, contribution increases and benefit reductions. The underfunded liability is expected to be further reduced over time through collective bargaining, increased market returns or other actions taken by plan trustees,” the company said.Shares in Safeway, which fell 3.4 per cent on Monday, recovered 0.7 per cent to $20.41.Apollo Group, the owner of the University of Phoenix, the largest US for-profit college, was among the worst-performing stocks on the main market, falling
8.5 per cent to $39.54.The education provider said its revenues in the first half of its 2012 fiscal year were hurt by a 15.6 per cent year-on-year drop in enrolments at its flagship school, while reports said the company’s chief executive predicted future enrolment rates would be “volatile”.Walgreen Co, the drugstore chain, rose 1.3 per cent to $34.80 even as it said second-quarter earnings fell 7.7 per cent to 78 cents a share. The company reported profits down almost 7 per cent to $683m, which it partially attributed to a mild cold and flu season.Amazon, the world’s largest online retailer, gained 1.3 per cent to $205.44 as the company said the seven book Harry Potter collection would now be available on its popular Kindle tablet.Bank of America dropped further away from the $10 threshold that it has been flirting with in the past few days. The bank was downgraded from “buy” to “hold” by analysts at Baird, who attributed the recent resurgence in the company’s shares – up 75 per cent in the year to date – to an unjustified fall in its price last year. Its shares fell 3.3 per cent to $9.60.“While BAC shares likely should have never been at $5 three months ago, at current prices we do not believe the intermediate-term earnings outlook justifies putting new money to work in the stock,” said David George, analyst at Baird.Pfizer, the world’s largest drugmaker, rose 1.5 per cent to $22.50 after a note from analysts at Goldman Sachs said that the company was willing to consider “separations beyond Animal Health and Nutrition if the conditions make sense”.Nabors, the land drilling contractor, was down 5.3 per cent to $17.79 as the company said it would sell $800m in non-core assets to raise funds.

Titular: US home prices end monthly declines
Texto: US home prices ended a long run of monthly declines in January, but the average cost of a home has fallen to the level of nearly a decade ago, an indication of how deeply the market has contracted since the financial crisis.The S&P/Case-Shiller home price index showed prices in January held flat on a seasonally adjusted basis after declining 0.5 per cent in December. Unadjusted, prices fell 0.8 per cent over the month.Year-on-year, prices extended their slump, dropping to a new post-crisis low. The January index fell 3.8 per cent against the same month in 2011, as analysts had forecast, compared with a 4.1 per cent fall in December. Prices have fallen 34.4 per cent from their bubble-era peak in 2006, and average home prices are back at 2003 levels.While some analysts pointed to signs of stabilisation in the property market, others were more cautious about the health of the housing market as indicated by a mixed run of data over the last week.“Despite some positive economic signs, home prices continued to drop …Atlanta, Chicago, Cleveland, Las Vegas, New York, Portland, Seattle and Tampa [all] made new lows,” said David Blitzer, chairman of S&P’s index committee.But he noted that “Detroit and Phoenix, two cities that have suffered massive price declines, plus Denver, saw increasing prices versus January 2011”.The index tracks monthly changes in the value of residential real estate in 20 metropolitan regions across the US. Due to delays in data reporting, the January 2012 index values for Charlotte, North Carolina were not included.Sixteen of the 19 cities included in January’s index showed a year-on-year decline. Only Miami, Phoenix and Washington home prices went up versus December 2011.Prices have been under downward pressure as a result of a glut of foreclosed properties and homes being sold at steep discounts, which have boosted the sales of existing homes. House prices lag home sales data by about nine to 12 months, according to analysts.David Stiff, chief economist at Fiserv, the financial services technology solutions company, said: “We are being presented with a confusing picture and we are likely to be bouncing along the bottom until early next year. It is going to be a bumpy ride and no one is going to have a clear idea that there is a sustained trend in one direction or another.”Mixed results for homebuilders illustrate the mixed outlook for the housing market.
